And it is narrated that Al-Muzani, may Allah have mercy on him, exited from the gate of the Mosque of Al-Fustat, and Ibn Abd al-Hakam approached in his procession, and he was dazzled by what he saw of his good condition and fine appearance, so he recited the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'And We have made some of you a trial (fitnah) for others: will you have patience (tasbirun)?' Then he said: 'Yes, I will have patience (asbir) and be content.' And he was poor and destitute. So the one who is in his home is not tested with such trials (fitan). For whoever witnesses the adornment of the world, either his religion (din) and certainty (yaqin) strengthen, and he has patience (yasbir) until he swallows the bitterness of patience (sabr), and it is a command from patience (sabr); or his desire (raghbah) is stirred, and he schemes in seeking the world, and he perishes an eternal perishing. As for in the world, then through covetousness (tama') which fails in most times, for not everyone who seeks the world finds it facilitated for him. And as for in the Hereafter, then through his preferring the enjoyment of the world over the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted and drawing near to Him.

So he was arrogant towards Allah and towards all His Messengers.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Indeed, Allah has condemned arrogance in multiple places of His Book and condemned every tyrant who is arrogant. So He, the Exalted, said: "I will turn away from My signs those who are arrogant on earth without right." And He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "Thus does Allah seal over every heart of an arrogant tyrant." And He, the Exalted, said: "And they sought victory, and every obstinate tyrant was disappointed." And He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, He does not love the arrogant." And He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, they have become arrogant in their souls (Anfus) and transgressed a great transgression." And He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, those who are arrogant toward My worship will enter Hell in humiliation." And the condemnation of arrogance in the Quran is abundant. And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "He will not enter Paradise who has in his heart (Qalb) the weight of a mustard seed of arrogance, nor will he enter Hell who has in his heart (Qalb) the weight of a mustard seed of faith." And Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Allah, the Exalted, says: 'Grandeur (Kibriya) is My cloak and majesty (Izzah) is My garment. So whoever contends with Me for one of them, I will cast him into Hell, and I do not care.'" And from Abu Salamah ibn Abd al-Rahman, he said: Abdullah ibn Amr and Abdullah ibn Umar met at al-Safa and stood together, then Ibn Amr departed and Ibn Umar remained weeping. They said: "What makes you weep, O Abu Abd al-Rahman?" He said: "This one - meaning Abdullah ibn Amr - claimed that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: 'Whoever has in his heart (Qalb) the weight of a mustard seed of arrogance, Allah will throw him on his face into Hell.'" And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "A man continues to go with his soul (Nafs) until he is written among the tyrants, and then befalls him what befell them of punishment." And Sulayman ibn Dawud (peace be upon them both) said one day - to the birds, humans, jinn, and beasts: "Come out," so they came out in two hundred thousand humans and two hundred thousand jinn, and he was raised until he heard the clamor of the angels glorifying in the heavens, then he was lowered until his feet touched the ground.

Just as when one marries and has intercourse and ejaculates, he remains hesitant about the child, fearing and hoping for the favor of Allah in creating the child and warding off afflictions from the womb and from the mother until it is complete, he is wise. Similarly, if one believes and does righteous deeds and abandons sins and remains hesitant between fear and hope, fearing that it will not be accepted from him and that it will not last for him and that he will be sealed with evil, and hoping from Allah the Exalted that He will establish him with the firm word and protect his religion from the thunderbolts of the agonies of death until he dies upon monotheism (Tawhid), and guards his heart (Qalb) from inclining toward desires for the remainder of his life so that he does not incline toward sins, he is wise. And whoever is other than these, they are the ones deluded by Allah "And they will know, when they see the punishment, who is more astray in way - and you will know its news after a while." And at that time they will say as Allah informed about them: "Our Lord, we have seen and heard, so return us; we will do righteousness. Indeed, we are certain." That is, we have learned that just as a child is not born except by intercourse and marriage, and a crop does not grow except by plowing and sowing seed, similarly, reward and recompense are not attained in the Hereafter except by righteous deed, so return us, we will do righteous deeds, for we have now learned the truth of Your saying: "And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives, and that his effort is going to be seen - Whenever a company is thrown into it, its keepers ask them, 'Did there not come to you a warner?' They will say, 'Yes, a warner had come to us, but we denied...'" That is, did we not hear you about the way of Allah (Sunnah) with His servants and that "Every soul will be fully repaid [for] what it earned" and that "Every soul, for what it has earned, is held in pledge"? ğŸ“– Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And among them is extravagance in food and building, which is reprehensible. Rather, in wealth there are two reprehensible acts: one is wastefulness and the other is extravagance. Wastefulness is squandering wealth without any benefit that is considered, like burning a garment, tearing it, demolishing a building without purpose, and throwing wealth into the sea. In its meaning is spending wealth on lamentation and entertainment and in types of corruption, because they are benefits prohibited by law, so they become as if non-existent. As for extravagance, it may be used to mean spending wealth on lamentation, entertainment, and reprehensible acts, and it may be used for spending on permissible things in their kind but with excessiveness. And excessiveness differs relative to circumstances. So we say: whoever owns only one hundred dinars, for example, and has his dependents and children with no livelihood for them except it, then spends it all on a feast, he is extravagant and must be prevented. Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not extend it all extension, so you sit blamed, destitute.' This was revealed regarding a man in Medina who distributed all his wealth and left nothing for his dependents, then was required for maintenance and could not afford anything. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not squander wastefully; indeed, the squanderers are brothers of the devils.' And likewise, Allah the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And those who, when they spend, are not extravagant and are not stingy, and it is between that a standing.' So whoever is extravagant with this extravagance is censured, and it is obligatory upon the judge to impose guardianship on him, except if the man is alone and has a true strength in reliance (Tawakkul), then he may spend all his wealth in paths of good. And whoever has dependents or is incapable of reliance (Tawakkul), it is not for him to give all his wealth in charity. And likewise, if he spends all his wealth on carvings of his walls and adorning his building, that is also prohibited extravagance. Doing that from one who has abundant wealth is not prohibited, because adornment is from sound purposes, and mosques have not ceased to be adorned and their doors and ceilings carved, even though carving the door and ceiling has no benefit except mere adornment, so likewise houses. And likewise the statement regarding beautification with garments and foods, that is permissible in its kind and becomes extravagance by consideration of the man's condition and wealth. And examples of these reprehensible acts are many and cannot be enumerated.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
And what indicates that what is sought is the middle path in character traits without the two extremes is that generosity is a praiseworthy trait religiously, and it is a middle between the two extremes of wastefulness and stinginess. And Allah the Exalted praised it by saying: "And those who, when they spend, are neither wasteful nor stingy, and there is a balance between that." And He said: "And do not make your hand chained to your neck nor extend it completely." Likewise, what is sought in the appetite for food is moderation without greed and rigidity. Allah said: "And eat and drink and do not be wasteful, indeed He does not love the wasteful." And He said regarding anger: "Severe against the disbelievers, merciful among themselves." And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "The best of matters are their middle ones." This has a secret and verification, which is that happiness is tied to the soundness of the Heart (Qalb) from the afflictions of this world. Allah said: "Except he who comes to Allah with a sound Heart (Qalb)." And stinginess is from the afflictions of the worldly life, and wastefulness is also from the afflictions of the worldly life, and the condition of the Heart (Qalb) is that it be sound from both of them, meaning it is not attentive to wealth nor is it eager to spend it nor to withhold it, for the one eager to spend has his Heart (Qalb) diverted to spending just as the one eager to withhold has his Heart (Qalb) diverted to withholding. So the perfection of the Heart (Qalb) is that it be purified from both descriptions altogether. And if that is not attainable in this world, we seek what is most similar to the absence of both descriptions and farthest from the extremes, which is the middle, for the lukewarm is neither hot nor cold but rather a middle between them, so it is as if it is free from both descriptions. So likewise generosity is between wastefulness and stinginess. And courage is between cowardice and recklessness. And chastity is between greed and rigidity. The totality of these words does not encompass the reality of generosity (al-Jood) and miserliness (al-Bukhl), rather we say: Wealth is created for a wisdom and purpose, which is its suitability for the needs of creation, and it is possible to withhold it from spending on what it was created to be spent on, and it is possible to give it by spending on what is not proper to spend on, and it is possible to manage it with justice (al-Adl), which is to preserve where preservation is obligatory, and to give where giving is obligatory. So withholding where giving is obligatory is miserliness, and giving where withholding is obligatory is wastefulness. Between them is a middle path which is praiseworthy, and it is appropriate that generosity (al-Sakhaa') and generosity (al-Jood) be an expression of it; for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was not commanded except with generosity, and it was said to him: 'And do not make your hand chained to your neck nor stretch it forth to the utmost limit' (Quran 17:29), and Allah the Exalted said: 'And those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor stingy, and there is a firmness between that' (Quran 25:67). So generosity (al-Jood) is the middle between extravagance (al-Israaf) and stinginess (al-Iqtar) and between stretching forth (al-BasT) and holding back (al-QabD), and it is to measure his giving and withholding according to what is obligatory, and it is not sufficient that he does that with his limbs unless his heart (al-Qalb) is content with it, not disputing him in it. For if he gives in a place where giving is obligatory and his soul (al-Nafs) disputes him and he endures it, he is forcing himself and is not generous, rather it should be that his heart (al-Qalb) has no connection with wealth except from where wealth is intended for him, which is spending it on what it is obligatory to spend it on.
